comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Likely misspelled, Russian Admiral Avellan. Looking for a good source...

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Here's one: The navy, like the army, had been reorganized, but in 1904 it was still a motley collection of ships. As president of the Admiralty, Grand Duke Alexis had under him Admiral Fyodr Karlovitch Avellan, the navy minister, and ten admirals, twenty-eight vice-admirals, thirty-seven rear-admirals, and thirty-five senior staff officers. Admiral Avellan had been a seagoing admiral, but he was no strategist. — Denis Ashton Warner, Peggy Warner: The tide at sunrise: a history of the Russo-Japanese War, 1904-1905 (Routledge, 2002) Also: Avellan, Fedor Karlovich, Admiral (1839–1916), Russian admiral, minister of marine 1903–5 — F. R. Bridge; From Sadowa to Sarajevo: the foreign policy of Austria-Hungary, 1866-1914 (Routledge, 2002)
